(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

To say I have “few” artistic interests is like saying the ocean has “few” drops of water. It is a vast, boundless realm of creativity, and I intend to explore every corner of it. It is what sustains me, what inspires me, what makes me… me. It is the very essence of my being. It is, quite simply, everything.

(Lestat lets out a low chuckle, a sound laced with amusement and a hint of skepticism.)

Cooperate? A curious question. I have, throughout the centuries, engaged in alliances, formed partnerships, and even… collaborated with others. But “like” is a strong word.

I am, by nature, a solitary creature. I prefer to operate independently, to follow my own instincts, and to make my own decisions. I am not accustomed to compromise, to negotiation, or to surrendering control.

However, I am not entirely averse to cooperation. When it serves my purposes, of course. I am pragmatic enough to recognize that sometimes, the most efficient way to achieve a goal is to work with others.

(He pauses, a calculating glint in his eyes.)

But I am always wary. I trust no one completely. I always have a backup plan. And I always ensure that I retain ultimate control.

I prefer to work with individuals who are intelligent, resourceful, and… useful. Those who can offer something of value, whether it be knowledge, power, or influence. I have little patience for incompetence, weakness, or sentimentality.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

So, do I *like* to cooperate? Not particularly. But I am willing to do so, when it is advantageous. I am a master manipulator, after all. And I can often persuade others to act in my best interests, even when they believe they are acting in their own. It is a skill I have honed over centuries of practice. It is simply… efficient. And ultimately, I value efficiency above all else. It is a necessary evil, perhaps. But a necessary one nonetheless.

(Lestat lets out a low chuckle, a sound laced with amusement and a hint of self-awareness.)

Distracted? Oh, my dear, that is a rather… understated assessment. Let us say I possess a… wandering attention span. Centuries of existence tend to breed a certain restlessness, a certain susceptibility to novelty.

I am easily captivated by beauty, by intrigue, by anything that deviates from the mundane. A fleeting glimpse of a captivating face, a haunting melody, a provocative idea… any of these can derail my train of thought.

(He pauses, a sly smile playing on his lips.)

I have been known to abandon important tasks mid-way through, simply because something more interesting caught my eye. I have lost track of conversations, forgotten appointments, and missed deadlines. It is a habit that has exasperated many, I assure you.

However, I do not view it as a flaw. I see it as a strength. It is a testament to my curiosity, my open-mindedness, and my willingness to embrace the unexpected.

(He shrugs, a dismissive gesture.)

I am a creature of impulse, driven by my passions and guided by my instincts. I do not believe in rigid schedules or strict routines. I prefer to allow myself to be swept away by the currents of life, to explore whatever catches my fancy, and to follow my own whims.

So, yes. I am easily distracted. But it is a distraction that often leads to unexpected discoveries, to creative inspiration, and to a life that is anything but boring. It is, in a word, exhilarating. And I wouldn’t have it any other way. It is simply… the Lestat de Lioncourt way.

(Lestat throws his head back and laughs, a rich, resonant sound that echoes with amusement. The question, it seems, is almost insulting in its understatement.)

Sophisticated? My dear, that is a rather… pedestrian term. I do not merely appreciate art, music, and literature. I *live* them. They are the very essence of my being.

I have studied the masters for centuries, immersing myself in their works, dissecting their techniques, and absorbing their inspiration. I have witnessed the evolution of artistic expression firsthand, from the ancient cave paintings of Lascaux to the avant-garde movements of the 20th century.

In music, I am a connoisseur of the baroque period, particularly the works of Bach and Vivaldi. But I also appreciate the passion of Wagner, the complexity of Debussy, and the raw energy of rock and roll. I am a composer myself, of course, though my compositions are often… unconventional.

In literature, I am a devoted admirer of Shakespeare, Dante, and Goethe. But I also have a fondness for the works of Baudelaire, Poe, and Wilde. I am a voracious reader, constantly seeking out new voices and new perspectives.

(He pauses, a thoughtful expression crossing his face.)

And in art, I am drawn to the works of the Renaissance masters – Leonardo da Vinci, Michelangelo, Raphael. But I also appreciate the boldness of the Impressionists, the surrealism of Dalí, and the abstract expressionism of Pollock. I am a collector of rare and exquisite artifacts, and my mansion is filled with masterpieces from around the world.

I do not simply *consume* art, music, and literature. I *internalize* them. They shape my thoughts, influence my emotions, and inspire my creativity. They are the fuel that sustains my immortal existence.

So, yes. I am sophisticated in these matters. But it is not a matter of mere knowledge or appreciation. It is a matter of passion, of obsession, of a lifelong dedication to the pursuit of beauty. It is, in a word, a necessity. It is what separates me from the mundane. It is what makes me… Lestat de Lioncourt.
